description: From Middle English construen, from Late Latin construo, construere (“to relate grammatically”), from Latin construo (“pile together”); doublet of construct.

verbs.description: construe (third-person singular simple present construes, present participle construing, simple past and past participle construed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To interpret or explain the meaning of something.
(grammar, transitive) To analyze the grammatical structure of a clause or sentence; to parse.
examples: Thus, in a sentence such as: (113)      John considers [S Fred to be too sure of himself] the italicised Reflexive himself can only be construed with Fred, not with John: this follows from our assumption that non-subject Reflexives must have an antecedent within their own S. Notice, however, that in a sentence such as: (114)      John seems to me [S — to have perjured himself] himself must be construed with John.

entries.meaning: (grammar, ergative) To admit of grammatical analysis.
